Here, we’ll be parsing our jupyter notebook from a random github link, and reading it out into markdown:
Markdown = markdown Code = markdown code block Code output = Images/code block Furthermore, we will fetch a github repo and automatically update it, when the file at the given like has been updated.
Latstly, we’ll be able to stack multiple notebooks into one ‘project’.
Running scripts on website Since our site is static, we’ll need to have a built-in link to displaying our github page, and automatically converting it to markdown somehow inbetween.
First, let’s do a test. We’ll load in the raw code from an arbitrary github file, and just change the first letter; to make sure we can handle changing, and loading dynamic content.
Running Javascript Let’s try to run a script that will do something to the file we call it in (client-side).
First, we create a javascript file in /static/javascript
Modifying Markdown post Now that we can run our javascript, let’s make a change to the file that we’ve inserted the script on (any file with my_script: true).
Then we can simply call it with:
--- title: "Your Post Title" date: '2024-12-19T16:39:50-05:00' jsFiles: - "/js/remote-content.js" --- We must include in our header-file now:
{{- if and .IsPage .Params.jsFiles -}} {{- range .Params.jsFiles -}} <script defer src="{{ . }}"> </script> {{- end -}} {{- end -}} To breifly explain this code, we are
checking if our page is actually a blog post checking if we have js file params, and reading it. adding the script to the header. Program Now, we must actually write the program. Note that javascript only modifies the html file that is sitting on-top of the markdown file. For our purposes, we just change the markdown with a javascript function.
To understand how our markdown is loaded in an html document, we can look at our themes ‘single.html’ file, which is a mix of html and css.
We can see in our file, we have our content loaded as :
{{- if .Content }} <div class="post-content"> {{- if not (.Param "disableAnchoredHeadings") }} {{- partial "anchored_headings.html" .Content -}} {{- else }}{{ .Content }}{{ end }} </div> {{- end }} ok, so what is .Content, and how can we modify it?

content:
1. Sharing Knowledge With this blog I aim to share my projects, which are manifestations of my learning through my own thinking, and learning from the knowledge created by others.
I will attempt to make this blog high-quality, educational, and dense in knowledge/learning!
2. Community I am writing here, because I beleive that sharing with the community is a great way to motivate myself, and to truly push myself to further understand. I hope that you comment on my post, share feedback, and criticize!
I’d imagine something like this to describe why sharing with the community can be beneficial:
While this is very un-nuanced, I still think it is good, and somewhat describes why knowledge should be shared!
3. Depth of knowledge The most important part of this blog is learning and deeply understanding. With every project/post, I will be asking the question: how can I dig deeper? This inevitably involves building-things out and challenging the mind with ‘mental (work)thinkouts’, and thinking through/spending time with subjects.
